title: First Archigram publication in 50 years out on Circa Press
author: EE17
excerpt: Archigram, the revolutionary architectural collective that reshaped the discipline in the 1960s and 70s, is back with Archigram 10, 50 years after their last issue. Published by Circa Press and edited by founding member Peter Cook, the new edition features contributions from original members...
text: anchor Archigram, the revolutionary architectural collective that reshaped the discipline in the 1960s and 70s, is back with Archigram 10, 50 years after their last issue. Published by Circa Press and edited by founding member Peter Cook, the new edition features contributions from original members Dennis Crompton, David Greene, and Michael Webb, alongside architects and critics from across generations and continents, including Hitoshi Abe, Odile Decq, and Thom Mayne. Known for their neo-futurist, Pop Art-inspired visions of architecture, Archigram continues to challenge conventional thinking, now exploring digital influences and natural inspirations. Archigram 10 is supported by ABB and packed with the group's signature imaginative drawings, rekindling their enduring spirit of experimentation and innovation.
html:
• anchor

    Archigram, the revolutionary architectural collective that reshaped the discipline in the 1960s and 70s, is back with Archigram 10, 50 years after their last issue. Published by Circa Press and edited by founding member Peter Cook, the new edition features contributions from original members Dennis Crompton, David Greene, and Michael Webb, alongside architects and critics from across generations and continents, including Hitoshi Abe, Odile Decq, and Thom Mayne.

    Known for their neo-futurist, Pop Art-inspired visions of architecture, Archigram continues to challenge conventional thinking, now exploring digital influences and natural inspirations. Archigram 10 is supported by ABB and packed with the group's signature imaginative drawings, rekindling their enduring spirit of experimentation and innovation.


    Â
